text:
I don't get that sentiment. I see it often, but I don't understand what exactly they mean...
• Do they mean that Julia's JIT + big runtime is unacceptable for phones, systems software and games, so there must only be scientific computing left?
• Do they mean the ecosystem only have cool packages for science, so it's not worth learning?
• Do they mean the compiler is built to only do science stuff? (How would that even work)

Do they mean the ecosystem only have cool packages for science, so it's not worth learning?
Do they mean the compiler is built to only do science stuff? (How would that even work)

text: I've heard fragments of all three.... along with the way code is organized (module system or misunderstanding MD)

text:
The first is somewhat correct - there's also web development, but I can't think of other good use cases given Julia's latency, unpredictability and memory usage.
The second is not quite true, but almost. The third, not so much though

text:
> along with the way code is organized (module system or misunderstanding MD)
Well, I don't think it's an uncommon opinion that our module system leaves something to be desired. At least that's how I feel, and I know a lot of people prefer more deterministic module organization the way Python, Rust, Elixir, and others do it

text: <@UDGT4PM41> you never know when you hit a previously uncompiled path, or when GC kicks in, and having code run and pass tests is not a guarantee that inference worked out. In contrast, having inferred code suddenly not infer in a static language is a breaking change, so you don't get those regressions

So Julia's Runtime takes what 250mb RAM? That's a lot. It wasn't super long ago that Consider an entire OS (Android) ran on a minimum of 512mb.

text:
I'm eagerly awaiting Juliansamaroos work and hope it hits production level stability. But in the mean time - it doesn't exist yet.

Like hypothetically haskell can outpace C - but in reality it doesn't. People in industry(people talking about phones, embedded systems, etc), aren't looking for "potential" unless that "potential" is useful or gives a competing edge. Writing a compiler for Julia to lessen it's runtime is a lot of work compared to something off the shelf with gaurantees, certifications, and specifications. Most people who are making these sorts of statements aren't saying them to bash julia at all or its potential. They are just saying - "hey right now as I understand it - I can't use it, it's way too bloated or requires a specialized team and half a year with an uncertain ROI".

Basically its people being practical.

text:
It doesn't require writing a compiler, the compiler already exists in the form of GPUcompiler.jl. It can already compile static julia code with no runtime dependency, that's what CUDA.jl does. It's about tweaking things to work better and separating out the runtime from the codegen. <@U6A0PD8CR> can give more info.

I'm not claiming Julia bashing. I'm just saying that people aren't aware of its potential or upcoming work when they make those statements. If that's not enough, I understand.

What I'm griping about is when the claims are purely facile, based on a superficial comparison to Matlab or sci/ml marketing.

elements.text: It doesn't require writing a compiler, the compiler already exists in the form of GPUcompiler.jl. It can already compile static julia code with no runtime dependency, that's what CUDA.jl does. It's about tweaking things to work better and separating out the runtime from the codegen.

can give more info.

text: <@UAEJRV3KJ> right now it's scattered across several repos but I think eventually it will be in package compiler

elements.text: right now it's scattered across several repos but I think eventually it will be in package compiler

text: I have a branch where I'm separating out the runtime component from `libjulia`, which is considerably smaller than the codegen component (and won't link dynamically against LLVM). But the main difficulty will be getting most patterns of code to nicely compile under GPUCompiler. Right now, dynamic dispatch is explicitly disallowed, but a lot of real code relies on a little bit of dynamic dispatch, so that restriction needs to be lifted.

elements.text: I have a branch where I'm separating out the runtime component from
libjulia

, which is considerably smaller than the codegen component (and won't link dynamically against LLVM). But the main difficulty will be getting most patterns of code to nicely compile under GPUCompiler. Right now, dynamic dispatch is explicitly disallowed, but a lot of real code relies on a little bit of dynamic dispatch, so that restriction needs to be lifted.

text: Also, most of Julia's bloat is in the sysimage, not in `libjulia` itself (although `libjulia` loads the sysimage at init time). What people really want is the ability to forego loading the sysimage, and instead re-JIT the required support code from Base/stdlibs into their own self-contained binary (which is what GPUCompiler already accomplishes quite well).

libjulia
itself (although
libjulia

loads the sysimage at init time). What people really want is the ability to forego loading the sysimage, and instead re-JIT the required support code from Base/stdlibs into their own self-contained binary (which is what GPUCompiler already accomplishes quite well).

text: Still, I have only so much time to work on this. If I were looking to deploy an application in the next 6 months that couldn't accept Julia's JIT overhead, I would write the low-level parts in C, and then use GPUCompiler to generate the numerical Julia pieces as a .o to be linked against.

elements.text: Still, I have only so much time to work on this.
